III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
Description and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is late in completion of Updated Service Plans (USP).
Investigation On 6/4/25 Complainant reported a review hearing was postponed
due to Foster Care Worker not submitting documents as
requested, including a service plan that was reportedly not
completed on time. Follow-up contact occurred with Complainant
on 6/4/25. No additional information was provided.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted by email on 6/26/25.
FCW reported being assigned to the case in December 2024. Due
to one youth entering care after his siblings, the service plans
were separated in the MiSACWIS database. Due to a
misunderstanding by FCW, two separate service plans were
completed when they should have been merged into one service
plan for that review period. On 6/30/25 an interview was
completed with FCW via video call. FCW stated she completed
her first service plan on the case in February 2025 and the second
service plan in April 2025. FCW indicated she believed all service
plans were completed timely, although there was some confusion
regarding the dates at the beginning of the case, due to the plans
initially being separated for the youth.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was contacted by email on
6/26/25. On 7/1/25 an interview was completed with FCS via video
call. FCS confirmed there was an error at the beginning of the
case, due to the children in the family having separate service
plans that should have been merged. The first service plan in
February 2025 was completed timely but needed to be redone to
include all of the children. This resulted in the USP being
completed past the due date.
Parent was interviewed by phone on 7/16/25. Parent reported
FCW did a good job staying in contact and communicating.
However, FCW was behind on a few things that impacted
progress on the case as court was postponed due to not having
the completed service plan and therapy reports.
2

Documents Reviewed:
• 9/25/24-10/24/24 Initial Service Plan, completed 10/24/24,
approved 10/27/24.
• 10/25/24-1/22/25 Updated Service Plan, completed 2/4/25
(12 days late), approved 2/18/25.
• 1/23/25-4/22/25 Updated Service Plan, completed 4/21/25,
approved 5/5/25.
Analysis A violation was found. Based on a review of the case file and
interviews with staff and Parent, it was determined the agency
completed one USP twelve days late.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was offered to ensure service plans only
cover the period in time in which has occurred. The 1/23/25-
4/22/25 Updated Service Plan was completed on 4/21/25,
however the end date of the report went until 4/22/25, one day
following the completion date. Anything that may have occurred
on 4/22/25 would not be captured on this Updated Service Plan
nor the next plan as that period would begin on 4/23/25.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the
Description foster parents in the development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to
and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the
child's family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not meet with mother.
Investigation On 6/4/25 Complainant reported that FCW failed to meet with
Parent as required. In a follow-up contact on 6/4/25, Complainant
stated FCW was a “slacker” and Parent could provide more detail.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted by email on 6/26/25
and interviewed by video call on 6/30/25. FCW stated Parent was
hesitant to meet with her recently, as Attorney (parent’s attorney)
3

advised against it. FCW believed Parent’s view of her was tainted
by Attorney. Initially Attorney was very happy with FCW and gave
a lot of praise for how the case was being handled. Then suddenly
Attorney changed their mind and the relationship with Parent
changed. FCW reported Attorney called her “stupid and
incompetent” and told Parent FCW was against her. FCW spoke
with Parent and gave reassurance that her goal was to be there
for Parent and the children, no matter what Attorney’s opinion
was. Parent sent an apology text to FCW regarding Attorney’s
actions. Parent continues to be involved in the case, attends
Family Team Meetings (FTM), and discusses services with FCW.
Parent is aware of what is required and has completed all of the
services needed. Unsupervised visits were recently granted and
the case continues to move toward reunification.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was contacted by email on
6/26/25 and an interview was completed via video call on 7/1/25.
FCS stated FCW and Parent had a good working relationship.
FCW met with Parent in person every month to discuss services
and the treatment plan. FCW also communicated with Parent via
phone call or text almost daily. However, it appeared Parent was
being negatively influenced by Attorney. During a recent FTM,
Attorney spoke poorly about FCW to the entire group. Parent
spoke up and corrected Attorney as some of the things she said
were inaccurate. Parent then texted FCW after the meeting and
apologized. At the time of this interview, FCS reported Parent and
FCW continued to have a positive working relationship.
Parent was interviewed by phone on 7/16/25. Parent reported
FCW did a good job staying in contact and communicating. Parent
stated she had a lot of contact with FCW regarding case services
and what was needed for reunification to happen. Parent stated
she “loves” FCW and “would never want another worker”. Parent
said FCW’s heart was in this case, she knew the case, and she
was working hard for Parent and the children. Parent reported she
did not have any concerns regarding FCW. Parent stated she had
several concerns regarding the DHHS Children’s Services
workers that initiated the investigation that brought the children
into care. Parent was informed DCWL does not regulate that area
of DHHS and provided Parent with contact information for the
Office of the Family Advocate.
Documents Reviewed:
• Case contacts were reviewed in MiSACWIS. There were
several phone, text and in person contacts between FCW
and Parent. Parent attended multiple FTMs with FCW and
4

signed PATPs indicating FCW reviewed the information
with her.
• Texts from Parent to FCW were reviewed. In summary,
Parent acknowledged that Attorney called FCW names and
said inappropriate things about her. Parent stated she did
not want another worker and knew FCW was doing her
best.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on documented case contacts and
interviews, it was determined the agency kept Parent informed of
case information and included Parent in case planning and
development.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
